content.description: Starts on obvious jug underneath suspended boulder and climbs straight out towards Peralta. Make a long reach to the jug to gain the top out through thuggy or technical means. Either way this one is a classic!
content.location: Large, UFO shaped suspended boulder that is leaned on the edge of the Fortress overlooking Peralta trail.Â

climbs.name: Stardust
climbs.fa: TR: Chris Raypole '88, Lead: Todd Swain '88

content.description: A steep, varied, and really fun pitch.  Begin on top of a boulder on good jugs.  Move into a left leaning finger crack and place a piece or two.  Fun, cruxy moves using pinches, pockets, and some hidden crimps get you up to the first bolt.  Do a long move to a pocket, followed by a cool high step.  More great pocket pulling through the next two bolts leads to the monster jug finish.   A bit of a run to the anchors afer the last bolt, but the difficulty eases considerably and the pockets are huge.
content.protection: A couple small peices. .4 or .5 and a small nut is all you need.  3 bolts.  2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Located on the steep, slightly overhanging face 10' right of Bay Tree Belay.

content.description: A bouldery start with large pockets.  Head up and left on ledges to a prominent crack.  Follow the crack to the top.  Can easily avoid any crack technique as there are plentiful features on either side (and also inside) of the crack.
content.protection: Medium gear. Gear anchor on top.
content.location: Located on the south face of The Fortress.  Begins on the far right side of the wall, right of a large overhang.  Scramble down, first north, then east back to the base.

content.description: This route starts about 10 feet to the left of the right edge of the face. Climb up and right on the steep wall past about four bolts to an anchor.
content.protection: About four bolts to a rappel anchor.
content.location: This route starts about 10 feet to the left of the right edge of the face.

content.description: Start on the obvious start hold underneath the large, impressive boulder on the south side of the fortress. Climb up to and past the amazing volcanic sloper (very atypical). Top out and walk off the side. Opening move is very difficult. Moving to and past the sloper is hard too.
This route starts up Pocketful of Rainbows and then continues up the steep wall to connect with a vertical finger crack.
content.protection: Climb past about four bolts to gain the finger crack. A nut or cam in the crack should get you to the rappel anchor.
content.location: This route starts about ten feet left of the right edge of the face (the line of Bon Bons in Space).

content.description:
P1:  Climb the thin crack that is easier that it looks from the ground.    Protection can be a bit fiddely, but a small nut protects the crux move perfectly.  After 60' the difficulty eases and you can traverse over to a 2 bolt anchor on the left or build a gear anchor at the base of the dihedral. 

  P2:  Climb up the obvious dihedral to the top.  Gear anchor. 

  Descent:  Walk off by scrambling to the NW and back around to the base.
content.protection: Mostly thin gear.  Small nuts, doubles of small cams, singles from 1"-3".  I found the smallest BD nut was great for the P1 crux.
content.location: Right in the middle of the South face of the Fortress.  40' right of the obvious Bay Tree Belay offwidth.

climbs.name: For a Few Pockets More
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, Chris Raypole, Greg Bender 1988

content.description: Fun pocket pulling and probably best done as a top rope.  Start on top of boulders on good jugs.  Pull up past crimps and pockets on sustained vertical terrain.  The first(and only) bolt is located after the crux about 30' up at a good rest.  Another 20' or so of 5.10 climbing gains the ledge with a 2 bolt anchor on the left.
content.protection: 1 bolt.  Could probably use some of the pockets to place tricams or small gear.
content.location: Center of the South face.  15' to the right of Bay Tree Belay.

content.description: Obvious big left angling corner up center of the West Face. Steep and somewhat loose with tricky pro. Fun moves though.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", walk off to the northeast

content.description: On the right edge of the Fortress (closest to the trailhead) is an arete with a pod at the base of the wall. Three bolts protect climbing up the arete.
content.protection: Three bolts protect the route. Rappel from an anchor.
content.location: On the right edge of the Fortress (closest to the trailhead) is an arete with a pod at the base of the wall.

climbs.name: Bay Tree Belay
climbs.fa: Larry Treiber, Erik Powell, and Chuck Parker 1972

content.description: Wide, featured crack goes from fist to OW, past ledge on right and up easier face moves to the top.
content.protection: A couple of big (6-8") pieces needed to lead safely, but can be easily toproped.
content.location: ~40' left of Freely Freaking on the west face of the Fortress

climbs.name: A Fistful of Pockets
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, Chris Raypole, & Greg Bender '88

content.description: Climb a finger crack that peters out after about 15'.  Clip the bolt and make the crux moves using good pockets and long moves.  Pass 1 more bolt and continue on easier terrain to a two bolt anchor on the left.
content.protection: 2 bolts.  Can find extra pro in the small pockets.
content.location: Look for the 15' finger crack 10' to the right of the obivous thin crack that is Feeling Freaky.

content.description: West and South facing crag.  150' formation overlooking the Peralta Trail.  A beautiful location with amazing views of the Supes, including Geronimo's cave.
